subject: Fashion
title: Mourning Clothes Across Cultures
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Mourning Clothes Across Cultures.

hook.text: In the West, black means mourning. In parts of Asia, white is the color of grief.

buildup.text: Queen Victoria wore black for 40 years after Prince Albert died, turning grief into a fashion statement.

discovery.text: Mourning colors are culturally invented. In South Africa, red signals grief. In Egypt, it's yellow.

twist.text: Victorian mourning rules were so strict that wearing the wrong shade too soon could ruin a reputation.

climax.text: Grief is universal. How we dress for it is entirely inventedâ€”proof that fashion is culture made visible.

punchline.text: Every culture grieves. Only fashion tells you what color.

quiz.question: What do varying mourning dress colors across cultures demonstrate?
options: Some cultures are more emotionally expressive than others in their grief
Color associations with death are genetically hardwired into human brains
Mourning dress customs are culturally invented, proving fashion reflects culture
